definitions.definition: one of the long parts that connect the feet to the rest of the body
definitions.labels: (informal)(formal)(British English)(British English)(disapproving)(both informal, often disapproving)(informal, disapproving)

examples.text: Sit on the floor, stretching your legs out in front of you.
your **left/right leg**
I **broke my leg** playing football.
She has a **broken leg**.
He **lost a leg** in a motorcycle accident.
She had to **have her leg amputated**.
How many legs does a centipede have?
The bear rose up on its **hind legs**.
a wooden leg
He dribbled the ball between the defender's legs.
I had a big bruise on my leg.
a **leg injury**
She jumped to avoid the flailing leg of the defender.
He put his back against the car, braced his legs and pushed.
She rose to her feet on shaky legs.
He sat down with his lame leg outstretched.
She sat with her legs dangling off the bridge.
He was shot in the leg by a sniper.
She was wheeled out of the hospital with her leg in plaster.
His legs buckled and he collapsed on the floor.
I moved the chair away from the table so I could cross my legs.
I was able to stand on my good leg.
I'm getting my legs waxed tomorrow.
It was good to get out of the car and stretch our legs.
Leg extensions use the quadriceps muscles to extend the knee.
Many birds are able to stand on one leg for hours at a time.
She crossed the finish line on tired legs.
He had his leg amputated below the knee.
She sat with her legs drawn up underneath her.
She stretched her legs under the table.
He swung his legs over the side of the bed and reached for his crutches.
The dog lifted its leg against the lamp post.
The dog sloped off, its tail between its legs.
They don't train the day before a match to ensure they have fresh legs.
They gazed at each other, their legs entwined under the table.
They made him put his hands on the police car and spread his legs.
They ran together, their legs moving in unison.
a fine pair of legs
an injury to his upper leg

definitions.definition: the leg of an animal, especially the top part, cooked and eaten

examples.text: Have you ever tried frogs' legs?
chicken legs
roast leg of lamb

definitions.definition: the part of a pair of trousers that covers the leg

examples.text: a trouser/pant leg
He rolled up the legs of his jeans.
These jeans are too long in the leg.

definitions.definition: one of the long thin parts on the bottom of a table, chair, etc. that support it

examples.text: a table/chair leg
He tripped over the leg of the chair.

definitions.definition: having the number or type of legs mentioned

examples.text: a three-legged stool
a long-legged insect

definitions.definition: one part of a journey or race

examples.text: The final leg of the trip was by donkey.
Hopefully, the next leg of the race will feature fewer icebergs and more dolphins.
We were on the last leg of our journey.
The fastest runner often runs the anchor leg (= the last part) of a relay race.

definitions.definition: one of a pair of matches played between the same opponents in a sports competition, which together form a single round (= stage) of the competition

examples.text: The Spanish team won the third leg.
I really believe we can turn around that 4–2 first leg deficit and win this game.

definitions.definition: to be going to die or stop functioning very soon; to be very weak or in bad condition
used to wish somebody good luck, especially to an actor before they go on stage
to cost/pay a lot of money
if you say that a news story, etc. has legs, you mean that people will continue to be interested in it for a long time
to be in a position where you are unable to prove something or explain why something is reasonable

examples.text: Without written evidence, we don't have a leg to stand on.

definitions.definition: to play a joke on somebody, usually by making them believe something that is not true
used to tell somebody to start to do something or to hurry
to go for a short walk after sitting for some time

examples.text: It was good to get out of the car and stretch our legs.

definitions.definition: to talk too much, especially about things that are boring or not important
feeling ashamed or unhappy because you have been defeated or punished

wordOrigin: Middle English (superseding shank): from Old Norse leggr (compare with Danish læg ‘calf (of the leg)’), of Germanic origin.
